body:
[Conditional compilation](http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html#conditional-compilation) is a feature that was inherited from Pyrex that never had a high standing amongst the Cython developers. It also takes up quite a bit of code space in the syntax nodes and the parser.

See the discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4287

I would like to deprecate it in Cython 3.0 and add a warning.
~It could be one of the things that we remove for Cython 3.1.~ It will not be removed in Cython 3.1, but continue to be available for another couple of release series, so that users have enough time to move away from it.

Usages should be replaced by:
- global cdef constants
- runtime conditions
- C macros, e.g. defined in [verbatim C code sections](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code)
- code generation
- leaving out unused struct field names from a struct definition
- redefining a struct type under different Cython names, with different (e.g. version/platform dependent) attributes, but with the [same cname string](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#resolving-naming-conflicts-c-name-specifications).

It is generally preferable to take a C compiler related decision at C compile time rather than Cython translation time. This avoids having to generate multiple versions of the C file. Especially platform dependent adaptations are really best handled in C macros, e.g.
```cython
cdef extern from "some_external_lib.h":
    """"
    #define HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD (C_LIB_VERSION >= 20)

    #if HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD
        #define _mylib_get_newly_added_field(a_struct_ptr)  ((a_struct_ptr)->newly_added_field)
    #else
        #define _mylib_get_newly_added_field(a_struct_ptr)  (0)
    #endif
    """"
    bint HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD
    int get_newly_added_field "_mylib_get_newly_added_field" (struct_ptr)

if HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD:
    print(get_newly_added_field(some_struct_ptr))
```

comment_data.body:
I'd be in favour in principle.

It might be worth trying to work out how much real code it'll break. I'm not completely sure the best way to do that right now - possibly by scraping [the PyPI dependent packages](https://libraries.io/pypi/Cython/dependents)?

A quick check of scipy turned up [this use](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/44e31b1eb202ef91caad059952ba268d2610a60b/scipy/stats/biasedurn.pyx.templ#L10) so at least one project would need some adapting.

```
DEF NPY_OLD = {NPY_OLD}
...
IF not NPY_OLD:
```

Although this is a niche feature, it can be used.
But I agree that the likelihood is high that there will be more pythonic ways to achieve the same result.
Both DEF and IF are quite useful for imports, since it doesn't make much sense to check for something at interpretation time that can be checked at compile time.

In short, DEF and IF benefit from whatever is determined at compile time.

While not many people think about it, what about UB/IB handling?
For example `INT_MIN / -1` for c++
in the case when `INT_MIN! = -INT_MAX` we must define the behavior of `INT_MIN / -1` ourselves, so as not to accidentally get stuck in an infinite loop, or so that our calculations do not suddenly return an incorrect result.
It is very convenient to wrap it in IF:

```cython
int safe_int_div(int a, int b):
    if b == 0:
        return 1

    IF INT_MIN != -INT_MAX:
        if a == INT_MIN and b == -1:
            return 1

    return a / b
```

Also numpy project is using them:

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/623bc1fae1d47df24e7f1e29321d0c0ba2771ce0/numpy/random/_philox.pyx#L14
pyimgui uses [DEF](https://github.com/pyimgui/pyimgui/blob/480b4de8ab82adaa2cd310100330b41f40274bcc/imgui/core.pyx#L37)
Some scipy tutorial uses [DEF](https://github.com/kwmsmith/scipy-2017-cython-tutorial/blob/3e72e31fc27dc1f44582926f4a01a4c29ee79abb/cython_mcmc/cython_mcmc/mcmc.pyx#L10-L11)

As I understand the discussion, `DEF` is OK, it is the `IF` that is more troubling (the "conditional" in "conditional compliation". Also: too many examples is going to make this discussion unwieldy. Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it. I apologize for starting it off.

> too many examples is going to make this discussion unwieldy. Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it.

of course, just a couple of examples, no more needed here
PyBoy uses [IF](https://github.com/Baekalfen/PyBoy/blob/b39a988e263d9830701d35d426fcd143d25e9ac9/pyboy/core/lcd.pxd#L30)

> ```cython
>     IF INT_MIN != -INT_MAX:
> ```

This is decidedly _NOT_ a use case for conditional compilation. It should be handled at C compile time.

> It should be handled at C compile time.

exactly, and as I understand it, cython cannot convert this expression to `#ifdef` and pass it to the compiler?

To clarify, what takes up code space is the separate calculation of constant values in the parser (i.e. `DEF`). The conditional statements (' IF'  etc.) are trivial compared to that. They are just a wart in the language.

I would personally like to see `IF` removed, at some point. I could live with keeping a way to define constants, although I don't think they'd have to be handled by the compiler. We already do constant folding (although we do not inject all constant values in the end, e.g. floats to prevent loss/gain of precision). I could imagine something like a `cython.once()` which would make sure that an expression is only evaluated once (and then cached, or, if compile time constant, injected as a constant at compile time). OTOH, I'm not sure it's worth breaking existing code for that.

The [use case in SciPy](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/44e31b1eb202ef91caad059952ba268d2610a60b/scipy/stats/biasedurn.pyx.templ#L77) is an exemplary one, if I understand it correctly. It seems to be using template code generation to inject a constant flag, but then uses `IF` to switch between different code sections. Why not use the templating language for that?

I'm sure users are still writing such code as we're discussing this, and IMHO they shouldn't. I've added a warning to the documentation and would also like to add a visible compile time deprecation warning. Would that be ok for everyone?

Then we can discuss the removal again in a couple of years from now, maybe with a better standing.

> Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it

here are some examples #4314
@scoder to fully understand when the behavior of `IF` will differ from `if`?  Or like what's the difference?

> @scoder to fully understand when the behavior of `IF` will differ from `if`? Or like what's the difference?

To be more specific, what legit `IF` expression will not have the same result as if we replace `IF` with `if`?

> add a visible compile time deprecation warning

That sounds like a good plan, and would encourage people to not use it.

I would be in favor of deprecating as well. 

Some `IF` expressions that would not be legal if replaced by if are those that use, for example, nonexistent or differently typed function calls in the different branches. (Either templating or a C-level shim can be used instead.)

It seems that most uses of `DEF` could be replaced by a global variable as well, though it's possible that would hurt the ability to optimize away some things at the C level even for a sophisticated compiler (for full expressions, literal constants should be fine). In a few cases (array sizes) we require a constant. Perhaps we could be smart enough here with an "ordinary" global.

Please be mindful of use cases like https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4291, which CuPy relies on a lot. Sorry I don't have time to open a discussion in the mailing list yet, but it doesn't mean I don't care...

cc: @kmaehashi

Yeah this is pretty useful when detecting the version of a dependency before adding certain code (like forward declarations or handling other differences between library versions). Have used `IF` to handle differences between Python versions specifically.

> As I understand the discussion, `DEF` is OK, it is the `IF` that is more troubling (the "conditional" in "conditional compliation"

Well, @mattip idk, but it looks like [`DEF` is not OK](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4286#issuecomment-887222354), at least @scoder doesn't really want to leave this in cython as I understand it

I added a deprecation warning for both `DEF` and `IF`, as well as some explanations and examples in the docs.

Please keep commenting in this ticket if you have a use case that is not easily replaced with something else.

What features should users be reaching for if they want to include/exclude a block of code based on a compile time setting?

For example optionally building with a library (say `liba.so`) where forward declarations and API calls to it should be included/excluded based on whether library is used during the build.

In general, C compile time features rather than Cython translation time features. Generating different C files is rarely a good idea.

A common thing to do is to write configuration dependent shims and then call those instead of the actual library API.

Removing `DEF` is OK, but without `IF` as part of the Cython compile-time preprocesser it's really hard to maintain the codebase without rolling out a code generator of our own.

cc: @kmaehashi @vzhurba01

I looked through CuPy a bit. There are large chunks of multiply defined structs like here:
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/76f3f85f14842685b4b8048f22536f39d2079c92/cupy_backends/cuda/api/_runtime_typedef.pxi
I certainly don't understand enough of it to give "final" answers (and this is the wrong place to discuss this in detail), but here are a couple of ideas how I could try to handle this. I [added examples](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code) to the docs.

For simple cases, I'd resort to writing C macro shims that give different implementations a common interface.

For more complex cases, especially with different but similar backend libraries, I'd consider implementing separate low-level extension modules and importing one or the other. I do not mean duplicating all of CuPy, not at all. But I'd investigate, for example, if I could provide a (shallow) common wrapper type with C methods that I could subclass into different implementations that work with different libraries in the end. That way, the different low-level structs and API differences would stay inside of those low-level modules, and the main user level API modules would only talk to the internal API of the low-level modules.

So, basically, the idea is to hide differences behind another level of indirection.

That said, this is what I would do when designing a new system. Applying this to an existing code base, especially an existing large code base, is … probably not done lightly. I'm aware that this is an issue.
I think https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2596 should be the most general way forward for this.

I'm changing the milestone to 3.0 because this ticket is about the deprecation. Removing the feature in 3.1 would be way too soon, but there will be a deprecation warning in 3.0 (and preferably already in 0.29.x) to keep new users from starting to use it in their code. The feature will probably stay available for another couple of years (and it wouldn't be the first such feature). That should give all of you enough time to move away from it and find better ways to do what you need.

Either [C macros](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code) or Cython code generation (#2596) should generally cover all use cases.

How should constants be declared right now? It doesn't actually seem like it's possible - as this [test shows](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/325641c5067163d5d20f3846e091a8cf18f1bfeb/tests/errors/const_decl_errors.pyx#L8), trying the following results in a "can't assign to const" error:
```cython
cdef const int x = 10
```
It does seem possible to workaround by using a verbatim C block, but that hides the constant's value from Cython preventing it from converting `if char in CONST_STRING` to a `switch`, which I'm using.

> How should constants be declared right now?

What's the specific need for constants? Is it missed optimisations (like your switch example) or are there more fundamental things that you need them for?

Python has largely taken the view that constants are a matter of convention rather than something that's enforced, so it isn't too unreasonable for Cython to take that view too (although not at the cost of blocking anything important from working...)

It's mostly optimisation yes, though as mentioned earlier there's things like array sizes that require constant values. Regular Python is mutable everywhere yes, but Cython is much more static in a lot of ways - monkeypatching builtins, extension classes, functions is ignored for the most part. Using `cdef` also would suggest you're after more C-like semantics.

The thing is, just to define a constant, we don't need the whole Python value computation machinery that `DEF` adds to the parser. It would be enough to define constants in `setup.py` and add them to some internal namespace. Or finally implement `cdef const ... =`. Or, inject them with code generation, which covers a whole lot more use cases.

`warning: View.MemoryView:323:0: The 'DEF' statement is deprecated and will be removed ...`
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Utility/MemoryView.pyx#L323

Not sure what the correct/new solution is, but bellow code should fix it!
``` cython
# replace:
DEF THREAD_LOCKS_PREALLOCATED = 8

# with:
cdef enum:
    THREAD_LOCKS_PREALLOCATED = 8
```
(Sorry I dropped the ball, bumping myself @leofang to check back asap.)

> `warning: View.MemoryView:323:0: The 'DEF' statement is deprecated and will be removed ...`

Fixed via code generation (which that module used anyway).
Why `DEF` cannot be used in version 0.29.30

> Why `DEF` cannot be used in version 0.29.30

It can, but it's deprecated. So you get a warning if you use it (not an error).

> > Why `DEF` cannot be used in version 0.29.30
> 
> It can, but it's deprecated. So you get a warning if you use it (not an error).

If I only used `DEF`, I will get nothing.If I used `DEF` to define  a constant in `pxd`, and used the constant in `pyx`, I will get
```
Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
# cython: language_level=3
from libc.stdio cimport printf


cpdef test():
    printf("%d", ArraySize)                ^
------------------------------------------------------------

test_DEF.pyx:6:17: undeclared name not builtin: ArraySize

```
test_DEF.pyx:
```
# cython: language_level=3
from libc.stdio cimport printf


cpdef test():
    printf("%d", ArraySize)
```
test_DEF.pxd:
```
# cython: language_level=3
DEF FavouriteFood = u"spam"
DEF ArraySize = 41
DEF OtherArraySize = 1 * ArraySize + 17

cdef int a0[ArraySize]
cdef int a1[OtherArraySize]
```
Is this something that worked before Cython 0.29.30 or new code?

> 这是在 Cython 0.29.30 或新代码之前有效的东西吗？

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44611975/176234099-934a4b85-0409-4e98-9407-62a71ebc343d.png)

It tried a few versions back to 0.28.1 and it didn't work on any of them. Therefore I think we just conclude that `DEF` variables do not cross the .pxd->.pyx boundary. Given that it's not a regression and a deprecated feature I think this is "won't fix"
Is there an option somewhere to treat compilation warnings as errors so we can make sure no deprecated API is used via CI ?

> Is there an option somewhere to treat compilation warnings as errors so we can make sure no deprecated API is used via CI ?

The cython command has a `-Werror` argument

> I added a deprecation warning for both `DEF` and `IF`, as well as some explanations and examples in the docs.
> 
> Please keep commenting in this ticket if you have a use case that is not easily replaced with something else.

Can you update the docs to show the correct way to do platform specific conditional statements.
https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html#conditional-statements

I saw that you added a partial example linked above but I don't know how to apply it to mac and linux.
https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code

My use case is importing functions from a dynamic library. I have platform conditional statements to define a function that loads the dll functions.
https://github.com/Amulet-Team/Amulet-Core/blob/fix-leveldb2/amulet/libs/leveldb/leveldb.pyx#L26-L57

@gentlegiantJGC in this example you can see that you write a code to include platform specific stuff
https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code
```cython
cdef extern from *:
    """
    #if defined(_WIN32) || defined(MS_WINDOWS) || defined(_MSC_VER)
      #include "stdlib.h"
      #define myapp_sleep(m)  _sleep(m)
    #else
      #include <unistd.h>
      #define myapp_sleep(m)  ((void) usleep((m) * 1000))
    #endif
    """
    # using "myapp_" prefix in the C code to prevent C naming conflicts
    void msleep "myapp_sleep"(int milliseconds) nogil

msleep(milliseconds=1)
```

Although I would recommend to just create a `.c` or `.h` file (of both) and then use `cdef extern from` on it:
```c
// independent.h
#if defined(_WIN32) || defined(MS_WINDOWS) || defined(_MSC_VER)
  #include "stdlib.h"
  #define myapp_sleep(m)  _sleep(m)
#else
  #include <unistd.h>
  #define myapp_sleep(m)  ((void) usleep((m) * 1000))
#endif
```
```cython
cdef extern from "independent.h":
    void myapp_sleep(int milliseconds) nogil

myapp_sleep(milliseconds=1)
```

In your case you can do the same thing with the platform specific code
And then just `cdef extern` so you will have access to the `getFunction`

It does seem like a bit of a step backwards because it requires writing pure C code to achieve something that could previously be done directly in Cython.
As a user that doesn't really know C it does make it a lot harder.
Here is my implementation.
<https://github.com/Amulet-Team/Amulet-LevelDB/blob/main/leveldb/_leveldb.pyx#L21-L73>

You don't have to move everything to c, only neessesary platform dependent parts
But yeah, I can see that documenation mey be little more helpful regarding this

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Deprecate conditional compilation
